title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: Romeb implements robust median‑based Bayesian growth curve modeling accommodate three classical missing‑data mechanisms—MCAR, MAR MNAR-complete data, particularly beneficial data nonnormally distributed include outliers. detailed tutorial can found Tang & Tong (2025).

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: main interface
code: Romeb(   Missing_Type,      # "MNAR", "MAR", "MCAR", or "no missing"   data,              # matrix / data frame   time,              # Numeric vector of measurement times (e.g., c(0,1,2,3)).   seed,              # reproducibility seed   K      = 0,        # number of auxiliary variables   chain  = 1,        # number of MCMC chains   Niter  = 6000,     # iterations per chain   burnIn = 3000      # burn‑in iterations )

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: Running returns compact table posterior median, Geweke z‑scores, 95% equal‑tail credible interval, 95% highest‑posterior‑density (HPD) interval monitored parameter. elements can accessed directly:
code: Res <- Romeb(...) print(Res)             # or simply type Res

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: illustrate workflow. Note: par [1]: latent intercept, par [2]: latent slope: par [3]: variance latent intercept, par [4]: covariance intercept slope, par [5]: variance latent slope.
code: set.seed(123) Y <- matrix(rnorm(300*5), nrow = 300, ncol = 5)  # tiny complete data set result_full <- Romeb("no missing", data = Y, time = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4), seed = 123) ## Compiling model graph ##    Resolving undeclared variables ##    Allocating nodes ## Graph information: ##    Observed stochastic nodes: 1500 ##    Unobserved stochastic nodes: 1804 ##    Total graph size: 14432 ##  ## Initializing model print(result_full) ## Romeb GCM summary ## ================== ##  ## Posterior medians (50% quantiles): ##       par[1]       par[2]       par[3]       par[4]       par[5]  ##  0.010448884  0.008549176  0.171543659 -0.056132922  0.046658630  ##  ## Geweke test: ##     par[1]     par[2]     par[3]     par[4]     par[5]  ## -0.4295213  0.8113677  0.1677203 -0.2686674  0.5478983  ##  ## 95% credible intervals: ##               2.5%       97.5% ## par[1] -0.08372728  0.09968858 ## par[2] -0.03105851  0.04984433 ## par[3]  0.09413207  0.27461789 ## par[4] -0.09527199 -0.02609691 ## par[5]  0.03244535  0.06536003 ##  ## 95% hpd intervals: ##            par[1]      par[2]     par[3]      par[4]     par[5] ## lower -0.08410641 -0.03164083 0.09030855 -0.09251707 0.03161084 ## upper  0.09900967  0.04894551 0.26590422 -0.02422712 0.06381646 ##  ## Use x$samps_full to access full MCMC samples, and coda::traceplot(x$samps_full[,'par[i]']) for the trace plot of par[i].

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
code: set.seed(456) Y <- matrix(rnorm(300 * 5), nrow = 300) miss <- runif(length(Y)) < 0.1       # 10% missing completely at random Y[miss] <- NA result_mcar <- Romeb("MCAR", data = Y, time = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4), seed = 456)

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
code: set.seed(789) X  <- matrix(rnorm(300 * 2), 300, 2)     # two auxiliaries Y  <- matrix(rnorm(300 * 5), 300, 5) Data <- cbind(X, Y) result_mnar <- Romeb("MNAR", data = Data, time = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4), K = 2, seed = 789)

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: Trace plot first chain (par[1])
code: # Uses the tiny example result_full from above coda::traceplot(result_full$samps_full[,'par[1]'])

title: Romeb Package: An Introduction
text: Please cite package : Tang,D.Tong,X.(2025). Romeb: R Package Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling Missing Data. Bibliographic metadata can also obtained via citation("Romeb").

title: Authors and Citation
text: Dandan Tang. Author, maintainer. Xin Tong. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tang D, Tong X (2025). Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling. R package version 0.1.2. Source: https://github.com/DandanTang0/Romeb, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=Romeb.
code: @Manual{,   title = {Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling},   author = {Dandan Tang and Xin Tong},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.2. Source: https://github.com/DandanTang0/Romeb},   url = {https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=Romeb}, }

title: Youth Attitudes toward Deviance (NYS, 1976–1980) — NYS
text: real data set 1976–1980 National Youth Survey U.S. youth.

title: Youth Attitudes toward Deviance (NYS, 1976–1980) — NYS
Youth Attitudes toward Deviance (NYS, 1976–1980) — NYS
text: data frame 1,725 rows 7 variables: age Participant age (years) gender Gender (0 = female, 1 = male) Atd1 Attitude toward social deviance, wave 1 Atd2 Attitude toward social deviance, wave 2 Atd3 Attitude toward social deviance, wave 3 Atd4 Attitude toward social deviance, wave 4 Atd5 Attitude toward social deviance, wave 5

title: Youth Attitudes toward Deviance (NYS, 1976–1980) — NYS
text: National Youth Survey, waves 1976–1980 (downloadable https://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/ICPSR/series/88)

what: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
text: Implements robust median-based Bayesian growth-curve models handle MCAR/MAR/MNAR missing-data mechanisms complete data. Models fitted via rjags/JAGS summarized coda. Fits median-based Bayesian growth curve model MCAR, MAR, MNAR complete-data assumptions.  K > 0 first K columns data treated auxiliary variables.

title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
code: Romeb(   Missing_Type,   data,   time,   seed,   K = 0,   chain = 1,   Niter = 6000,   burnIn = 3000 )

title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
text: Missing_Type Character; one MNAR, MAR, MCAR, missing. data Matrix data frame containing outcome columns (optionally auxiliary variables). time Numeric vector measurement times (e.g., c(0,1,2,3)). seed Integer seed reproducibility. K Integer; number auxiliary variables (default 0). chain Integer; number MCMC chains (default 1). Niter Integer; iterations per chain (default 6000). burnIn Integer; burn-iterations (default 3000).

title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
text: object class RomebResult containing quantiles posterior means, SDs quantiles geweke Geweke z-scores credible_intervals 95% equal-tail credible intervals hpd_intervals 95% highest posterior density intervals samps_full full coda::mcmc.list (including burn-)

title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
text: Maintainer: Dandan Tang tangdd20@gmail.com (ORCID) Authors: Xin Tong

title: Romeb: Robust Median-Based Bayesian Growth Curve Modeling — Romeb
code: set.seed(123)   Y <- matrix(rnorm(300), 100, 3)   fit <- Romeb("no missing", data = Y, time = c(0,1,2), seed = 123, K = 0,                Niter = 6000, burnIn = 3000) #>  #> Running no missing model  (K = 0) #> Compiling model graph #>    Resolving undeclared variables #>    Allocating nodes #> Graph information: #>    Observed stochastic nodes: 300 #>    Unobserved stochastic nodes: 404 #>    Total graph size: 3030 #>  #> Initializing model #>    print(fit) #> Romeb GCM summary #> ================== #>  #> Posterior medians (50% quantiles): #>       par[1]       par[2]       par[3]       par[4]       par[5]  #> -0.028959076  0.006534935  0.246008195 -0.139386679  0.191886602  #>  #> Geweke test: #>     par[1]     par[2]     par[3]     par[4]     par[5]  #>  0.6312252 -1.3194087  0.2727626  0.3205222 -0.7499546  #>  #> 95% credible intervals: #>               2.5%       97.5% #> par[1] -0.20424846  0.14309348 #> par[2] -0.13638706  0.15364752 #> par[3]  0.11134245  0.47052262 #> par[4] -0.31684374 -0.03367711 #> par[5]  0.08970286  0.35341840 #>  #> 95% hpd intervals: #>           par[1]     par[2]     par[3]     par[4]     par[5] #> lower -0.1968473 -0.1370647 0.09913653 -0.2846050 0.07818917 #> upper  0.1489117  0.1522016 0.43895060 -0.0121798 0.33646925 #>  #> Use x$samps_full to access full MCMC samples, and coda::traceplot(x$samps_full[,'par[i]']) for the trace plot of par[i].
